20101220230037.000|20101220230039.000|TR0|spying on you.

20101220230046.000|20101220230048.000|TR0|expected.
20101220230048.000|20101220230051.000|TR0|
20101220230051.000|20101220230053.000|TR0|Welcome to our viewers in the United 
20101220230053.000|20101220230055.000|TR0|States and around the world. Wolf Blitzer

20101220230058.000|20101220230100.000|TR0|exclusive assignment in North Korea.
20101220230100.000|20101220230102.000|TR0|

20101220230105.000|20101220230107.000|TR0|SITUATION ROOM.
20101220230107.000|20101220230109.000|TR0|
20101220230109.000|20101220230112.000|TR0|The fear of war in the Korean Peninsula, 
20101220230112.000|20101220230114.000|TR0|where the U.S. has 28,000 troops, has 
20101220230114.000|20101220230116.000|TR0|ratcheted down several notches.  North 
20101220230116.000|20101220230119.000|TR0|Korea blinked after the South conducted a 
20101220230119.000|20101220230121.000|TR0|military drill today using live 
20101220230121.000|20101220230123.000|TR0|ammunition, a move that North Korea had 
20101220230123.000|20101220230126.000|TR0|said might prompt military retaliation.
20101220230126.000|20101220230128.000|TR0|
20101220230128.000|20101220230130.000|TR0|The tension was the highest since 1953.  
20101220230130.000|20101220230133.000|TR0|Thousands of South Koreans were ordered 
20101220230133.000|20101220230135.000|TR0|into shelters ahead of the drill, but it 
20101220230135.000|20101220230137.000|TR0|ended after 90 minutes with no immediate 
20101220230137.000|20101220230140.000|TR0|reaction from the North and some 
20101220230140.000|20101220230142.000|TR0|diplomatic progress.
20101220230142.000|20101220230144.000|TR0|
20101220230144.000|20101220230146.000|TR0|The country now says it agrees to allow 
20101220230146.000|20101220230149.000|TR0|United Nations monitors access to its 
20101220230149.000|20101220230151.000|TR0|uranium enrichment facility, and it's 
20101220230151.000|20101220230153.000|TR0|willing to consider taking part in a 
20101220230153.000|20101220230156.000|TR0|military commission aimed at preventing 
20101220230156.000|20101220230158.000|TR0|future conflicts.
20101220230158.000|20101220230200.000|TR0|
20101220230200.000|20101220230203.000|TR0|That surprising reaction may be due to the 
20101220230203.000|20101220230205.000|TR0|presence of New Mexico Governor Bill 
20101220230205.000|20101220230207.000|TR0|Richardson.  He just left North Korea, 
20101220230207.000|20101220230210.000|TR0|along with our own Wolf Blitzer, after a 
20101220230210.000|20101220230212.000|TR0|four-day visit at the invitation of the 
20101220230212.000|20101220230214.000|TR0|North Korean government.
20101220230214.000|20101220230217.000|TR0|

20101220230219.000|20101220230221.000|TR0|just a moment, but first to the North

20101220230354.000|20101220230357.000|TR0|point, because he's been here many times 
20101220230357.000|20101220230359.000|TR0|over the years.
20101220230359.000|20101220230401.000|TR0|
20101220230401.000|20101220230404.000|TR0|What do you think, Governor?
20101220230404.000|20101220230406.000|TR0|
20101220230406.000|20101220230408.000|TR0|GOV. BILL RICHARDSON (D), NEW MEXICO:  
20101220230408.000|20101220230411.000|TR0|Well, potentially, I believe there's 
20101220230411.000|20101220230413.000|TR0|always a credibility problem with the 
20101220230413.000|20101220230415.000|TR0|North Koreans. But in my discussions with 
20101220230415.000|20101220230418.000|TR0|them, intensive discussions, after they 
20101220230418.000|20101220230420.000|TR0|did their propaganda and their points of 
20101220230420.000|20101220230422.000|TR0|view, there was more flexibility. Their 
20101220230422.000|20101220230425.000|TR0|tone was more positive, as if they 
20101220230425.000|20101220230427.000|TR0|realized they'd gone into the precipice 
20101220230427.000|20101220230429.000|TR0|with their very negative actions, like the 
20101220230429.000|20101220230432.000|TR0|shooting of the civilians and sinking of 
20101220230432.000|20101220230434.000|TR0|the ship, that maybe this was the time to 
20101220230434.000|20101220230436.000|TR0|stop that activity and reach out.
20101220230436.000|20101220230439.000|TR0|
20101220230439.000|20101220230441.000|TR0|And I believe that was involved in the 
20101220230441.000|20101220230443.000|TR0|decision to not respond militarily.  I 
20101220230443.000|20101220230446.000|TR0|pressed them not to.  I said, here's a 
20101220230446.000|20101220230448.000|TR0|great opportunity for you.  And then the 
20101220230448.000|20101220230450.000|TR0|discussions we had on allowing the IAEA 
20101220230450.000|20101220230452.000|TR0|monitors to come in on the purchase of the 
20101220230452.000|20101220230455.000|TR0|fuel rods.
20101220230455.000|20101220230457.000|TR0|
20101220230457.000|20101220230459.000|TR0|So, maybe this is an opportunity, a 
20101220230459.000|20101220230502.000|TR0|chapter in which the six- party countries 
20101220230502.000|20101220230504.000|TR0|can reach out to North Korea and say, OK, 
20101220230504.000|20101220230506.000|TR0|you have got to stop this bad activity.  
20101220230506.000|20101220230509.000|TR0|Now you have shown a little statesmanlike 
20101220230509.000|20101220230511.000|TR0|activity.  Now we're ready to talk.  Let's 
20101220230511.000|20101220230513.000|TR0|talk.  Let's get rid of your nuclear 
20101220230513.000|20101220230516.000|TR0|weapons.
20101220230516.000|20101220230518.000|TR0|
20101220230518.000|20101220230520.000|TR0|BLITZER:  Take us behind the scenes.  You 
20101220230520.000|20101220230523.000|TR0|met with the vice president of North 
20101220230523.000|20101220230525.000|TR0|Korea, the vice minister for foreign 
20101220230525.000|20101220230527.000|TR0|affairs, the chief nuclear negotiator.  
20101220230527.000|20101220230530.000|TR0|You met with Major General Pak Rim Su, the 
20101220230530.000|20101220230532.000|TR0|chief of the North Korean army, at the 
20101220230532.000|20101220230534.000|TR0|DMZ.  And you probably met with more North

20101220230537.000|20101220230539.000|TR0|official.  You're here as a private 
20101220230539.000|20101220230541.000|TR0|citizen.

20101220230555.000|20101220230558.000|TR0|
20101220230558.000|20101220230600.000|TR0|Yes, they gave their speeches, why they 
20101220230600.000|20101220230602.000|TR0|are they are, and the -- Kim Il-Sung and 
20101220230602.000|20101220230605.000|TR0|the leadership here.  But there was some 
20101220230605.000|20101220230607.000|TR0|flexibility. Their tone was different.  
20101220230607.000|20101220230609.000|TR0|They seemed to realize that they had maybe 
20101220230609.000|20101220230612.000|TR0|gone too far, and now was a time to reach 
20101220230612.000|20101220230614.000|TR0|out.
20101220230614.000|20101220230616.000|TR0|

20101220230619.000|20101220230621.000|TR0|proposals that I made were dealt with 
20101220230621.000|20101220230623.000|TR0|favorably on the IAEA, on the fuel rods, 
20101220230623.000|20101220230625.000|TR0|on the -- the military commission to 
20101220230625.000|20101220230628.000|TR0|monitor some of the activities on the West 
20101220230628.000|20101220230630.000|TR0|Sea. So I noticed a better tone, 
20101220230630.000|20101220230632.000|TR0|flexibility.  I noticed them wanting to 
20101220230632.000|20101220230635.000|TR0|reach back.

20101220230639.000|20101220230642.000|TR0|President Obama, the Obama administration?
20101220230642.000|20101220230644.000|TR0|

20101220230646.000|20101220230649.000|TR0|they have got some concerns.
20101220230649.000|20101220230651.000|TR0|
20101220230651.000|20101220230653.000|TR0|But there were several comments about how 
20101220230653.000|20101220230656.000|TR0|they like the president personally, that 
20101220230656.000|20101220230658.000|TR0|he -- he was somebody that was 
20101220230658.000|20101220230700.000|TR0|symbolically for the United States a great 
20101220230700.000|20101220230703.000|TR0|image.  But they're somehow right now at a 
20101220230703.000|20101220230705.000|TR0|point where they feel that they have been

20101220230714.000|20101220230717.000|TR0|
20101220230717.000|20101220230719.000|TR0|But, somehow, I believe they have made a 
20101220230719.000|20101220230721.000|TR0|decision to open up, to reengage.  Now,

20101220230724.000|20101220230726.000|TR0|to show deeds and not just words.  But I 
20101220230726.000|20101220230728.000|TR0|think their action of not responding 
20101220230728.000|20101220230731.000|TR0|militarily, of reaching out on some of

20101220230918.000|20101220230920.000|TR0|talks a great game.  They always do.  The 
20101220230920.000|20101220230922.000|TR0|real issue is, what will they do?
20101220230922.000|20101220230925.000|TR0|

20101220230927.000|20101220230929.000|TR0|inspectors to their country, they have to 
20101220230929.000|20101220230931.000|TR0|tell the IAEA that.  The big if is "if 
20101220230931.000|20101220230934.000|TR0|implemented."  We have seen a string of 
20101220230934.000|20101220230936.000|TR0|broken promises by North Korea going back 
20101220230936.000|20101220230938.000|TR0|many, many years.  We have -- as we have 
20101220230938.000|20101220230941.000|TR0|said all along, we will be guided by what 
20101220230941.000|20101220230943.000|TR0|North Korea does, not by what North Korea 
20101220230943.000|20101220230945.000|TR0|says it might do under certain 
20101220230945.000|20101220230948.000|TR0|circumstances.

20101220230952.000|20101220230955.000|TR0|
20101220230955.000|20101220230957.000|TR0|CROWLEY:  The American public is skeptical 
20101220230957.000|20101220230959.000|TR0|as well.  In a new CNN/Opinion Research 
20101220230959.000|20101220231002.000|TR0|Corporation poll, more than 80 percent of 
20101220231002.000|20101220231004.000|TR0|those asked see North Korea as posing some 
20101220231004.000|20101220231006.000|TR0|kind of threat to the U.S. -- 28 percent 
20101220231006.000|20101220231009.000|TR0|see an immediate threat -- 56 percent say 
20101220231009.000|20101220231011.000|TR0|North Korea poses a long-term threat to 
20101220231011.000|20101220231013.000|TR0|the U.S.  And 16 percent say the country 
20101220231013.000|20101220231016.000|TR0|poses no threat.
20101220231016.000|20101220231018.000|TR0|
20101220231018.000|20101220231020.000|TR0|We want to get some more on the South 
20101220231020.000|20101220231023.000|TR0|Korean military drill that sparked this 
20101220231023.000|20101220231025.000|TR0|latest crisis.
20101220231025.000|20101220231027.000|TR0|
20101220231027.000|20101220231030.000|TR0|CNN's Tom Foreman and CNN Pentagon 
20101220231030.000|20101220231032.000|TR0|correspondent Barbara Starr are here with 
20101220231032.000|20101220231034.000|TR0|the details.
20101220231034.000|20101220231037.000|TR0|
20101220231037.000|20101220231039.000|TR0|Tom, tell us exactly what South Korea did.
20101220231039.000|20101220231041.000|TR0|
20101220231041.000|20101220231044.000|TR0|TOM FOREMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT:  Well, 
20101220231044.000|20101220231046.000|TR0|what South Korea did was a drill right on 
20101220231046.000|20101220231048.000|TR0|the line of what makes North Korea

20101220231051.000|20101220231053.000|TR0|we did here.

20101220231700.000|20101220231703.000|TR0|TODD (voice-over):  On the streets of 
20101220231703.000|20101220231705.000|TR0|Memphis, a futuristic crime-fighting tool, 
20101220231705.000|20101220231707.000|TR0|squad cars equipped with license plate 
20101220231707.000|20101220231710.000|TR0|recognition cameras.  Turning on swivels, 
20101220231710.000|20101220231712.000|TR0|they scan plates, the images processed on 
20101220231712.000|20101220231714.000|TR0|laptops inside the police cars and in 
20101220231714.000|20101220231717.000|TR0|what's called a real-time crime center.
20101220231717.000|20101220231719.000|TR0|
20101220231719.000|20101220231721.000|TR0|In seconds, a display on his dashboard 
20101220231721.000|20101220231723.000|TR0|screen tells an officer if the car has 
20101220231723.000|20101220231726.000|TR0|been stolen, if there are warrants 
20101220231726.000|20101220231728.000|TR0|connected to it, maybe if the driver is a 
20101220231728.000|20101220231730.000|TR0|convicted felon.  Surveillance cameras

20101220231733.000|20101220231735.000|TR0|crime center are popping up all over

20101220231810.000|20101220231812.000|TR0|
20101220231812.000|20101220231815.000|TR0|TODD:  Dana Priest co-work a lengthy 
20101220231815.000|20101220231817.000|TR0|investigative story for "The Washington 
20101220231817.000|20101220231819.000|TR0|Post" on new high-tech tools and 
20101220231819.000|20101220231822.000|TR0|data-sharing used by Homeland Security and 
20101220231822.000|20101220231824.000|TR0|law enforcement.
20101220231824.000|20101220231826.000|TR0|
20101220231826.000|20101220231829.000|TR0|According to the article, more information 
20101220231829.000|20101220231831.000|TR0|is being collected on many of us and 
20101220231831.000|20101220231833.000|TR0|shared among more law enforcement agencies 
20101220231833.000|20101220231836.000|TR0|than ever before.  It's part of an 
20101220231836.000|20101220231838.000|TR0|often-heard post-9/11 mantra to catch 
20101220231838.000|20101220231840.000|TR0|potential terrorists.
20101220231840.000|20101220231843.000|TR0|
20101220231843.000|20101220231845.000|TR0|PRIEST:  To help the federal government 
20101220231845.000|20101220231847.000|TR0|find the dots, to find people who might be 
20101220231847.000|20101220231850.000|TR0|acting suspiciously.
20101220231850.000|20101220231852.000|TR0|
20101220231852.000|20101220231854.000|TR0|TODD:  The information goes to so-called 
20101220231854.000|20101220231856.000|TR0|fusion centers run by state and local law 
20101220231856.000|20101220231859.000|TR0|enforcement.  That's where data on 
20101220231859.000|20101220231901.000|TR0|suspicious behavior is shared with DHS, 
20101220231901.000|20101220231903.000|TR0|the FBI and other agencies.
20101220231903.000|20101220231906.000|TR0|
20101220231906.000|20101220231908.000|TR0|With an uptick in terror plots in recent 
20101220231908.000|20101220231910.000|TR0|years, a DHS official says this system has 
20101220231910.000|20101220231913.000|TR0|led to more arrests.  But privacy 
20101220231913.000|20101220231915.000|TR0|advocates say it also carries huge 
20101220231915.000|20101220231917.000|TR0|potential for abuse.
20101220231917.000|20101220231920.000|TR0|
20101220231920.000|20101220231922.000|TR0|Former FBI agent Michael German, now with 
20101220231922.000|20101220231924.000|TR0|the American Civil Liberties Union, says 
20101220231924.000|20101220231927.000|TR0|it empowers police to intervene more 
20101220231927.000|20101220231929.000|TR0|deeply into people's private lives.
20101220231929.000|20101220231931.000|TR0|
20101220231931.000|20101220231934.000|TR0|MICHAEL GERMAN, AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES 
20101220231934.000|20101220231936.000|TR0|UNION:  The behaviors they have described 
20101220231936.000|20101220231938.000|TR0|as inherently suspicious include things 
20101220231938.000|20101220231941.000|TR0|like taking notes, drawing diagrams, 
20101220231941.000|20101220231943.000|TR0|taking measurements, taking photographs or 
20101220231943.000|20101220231945.000|TR0|video, which are ubiquitous activities 
20101220231945.000|20101220231948.000|TR0|that all of us do.
20101220231948.000|20101220231950.000|TR0|
20101220231950.000|20101220231952.000|TR0|TODD (on camera):  But terrorists also do 
20101220231952.000|20101220231955.000|TR0|that, right?
20101220231955.000|20101220231957.000|TR0|
20101220231957.000|20101220231959.000|TR0|GERMAN:  I'm sure they do, but terrorists 
20101220231959.000|20101220232002.000|TR0|also put shoes on.  But that doesn't mean 
20101220232002.000|20101220232004.000|TR0|that somehow tracking every person who 
20101220232004.000|20101220232006.000|TR0|puts shoes on or every person who takes 
20101220232006.000|20101220232009.000|TR0|notes or every person who takes 
20101220232009.000|20101220232011.000|TR0|photographs is somehow a useful practice.
20101220232011.000|20101220232013.000|TR0|
20101220232013.000|20101220232016.000|TR0|(END VIDEOTAPE)
20101220232016.000|20101220232018.000|TR0|
20101220232018.000|20101220232020.000|TR0|TODD:  Michael German says previous 
20101220232020.000|20101220232023.000|TR0|investigations have found that, in some 
20101220232023.000|20101220232025.000|TR0|cases, law enforcement officials used 
20101220232025.000|20101220232027.000|TR0|technology and shared information to look 
20101220232027.000|20101220232029.000|TR0|at the private information of celebrities.
20101220232029.000|20101220232032.000|TR0|
20101220232032.000|20101220232034.000|TR0|Contacted by CNN, officials from the FBI 
20101220232034.000|20101220232036.000|TR0|and the Department of Homeland Security 
20101220232036.000|20101220232039.000|TR0|said they have strong programs in place to 
20101220232039.000|20101220232041.000|TR0|combat potential abuse and that 
20101220232041.000|20101220232043.000|TR0|unnecessary information is not added to 
20101220232043.000|20101220232046.000|TR0|any of these databases or kept in them -- 
20101220232046.000|20101220232048.000|TR0|Candy.
20101220232048.000|20101220232050.000|TR0|
20101220232050.000|20101220232053.000|TR0|CROWLEY:  Brian, is there any policy in 
20101220232053.000|20101220232055.000|TR0|place that would teach agents about 
20101220232055.000|20101220232057.000|TR0|protecting privacy?
20101220232057.000|20101220232100.000|TR0|
20101220232100.000|20101220232102.000|TR0|TODD:  Well, both agencies say they not 
20101220232102.000|20101220232104.000|TR0|only train their agents on those 
20101220232104.000|20101220232107.000|TR0|protections, but they're very clear on 
20101220232107.000|20101220232109.000|TR0|punishments that they will incur of those 
20101220232109.000|20101220232111.000|TR0|protections are broken.  And they do 
20101220232111.000|20101220232114.000|TR0|privacy impact assessments when they first 
20101220232114.000|20101220232116.000|TR0|get some of this information to make sure 
20101220232116.000|20101220232118.000|TR0|that it doesn't infringe on someone's 
20101220232118.000|20101220232121.000|TR0|privacy.  If it's unnecessary or it does 
20101220232121.000|20101220232123.000|TR0|so unnecessarily, it won't go into those 
20101220232123.000|20101220232125.000|TR0|databases.
20101220232125.000|20101220232128.000|TR0|

20101220234123.000|20101220234125.000|TR0|CROWLEY:  In a matter of hours and if the

20101220234127.000|20101220234130.000|TR0|is going to look a lot different.  People 
20101220234130.000|20101220234132.000|TR0|will be looking up to catch an unusual 
20101220234132.000|20101220234134.000|TR0|sight: a total eclipse of the moon. It's 
20101220234134.000|20101220234137.000|TR0|unusual, because this one comes during the 
20101220234137.000|20101220234139.000|TR0|winter solstice.
20101220234139.000|20101220234141.000|TR0|
20101220234141.000|20101220234144.000|TR0|How does this happen and where's the best 
20101220234144.000|20101220234146.000|TR0|place to see it?  CNN's meteorologist, 
20101220234146.000|20101220234148.000|TR0|Reynolds Wolf, joins me how to explain all 
20101220234148.000|20101220234151.000|TR0|of it.
20101220234151.000|20101220234153.000|TR0|
20101220234153.000|20101220234155.000|TR0|REYNOLDS WOLF, CNN METEOROLOGIST:  Well, 
20101220234155.000|20101220234158.000|TR0|Candy, believe it or not, you are in the 
20101220234158.000|20101220234200.000|TR0|best place to see it.  Not necessarily in 
20101220234200.000|20101220234202.000|TR0|the studio but in Washington, D.C. or 
20101220234202.000|20101220234205.000|TR0|anywhere along the eastern seaboard, sky 
20101220234205.000|20101220234207.000|TR0|conditions should be favorable to be able 
20101220234207.000|20101220234209.000|TR0|to look outside and see the moon and right 
20101220234209.000|20101220234212.000|TR0|through the hours of 1 a.m. and about 5 
20101220234212.000|20101220234214.000|TR0|a.m. Eastern Time, you should have a 
20101220234214.000|20101220234216.000|TR0|pretty good view of it, with the peak time 
20101220234216.000|20101220234218.000|TR0|being right around 3.
20101220234218.000|20101220234221.000|TR0|
20101220234221.000|20101220234223.000|TR0|The idea of a lunar eclipse is not the 
20101220234223.000|20101220234225.000|TR0|thing that's so unusual. It's that it 
20101220234225.000|20101220234228.000|TR0|coincides with the winter solstice.  The 
20101220234228.000|20101220234230.000|TR0|last time that happened was back in 1554.  
20101220234230.000|20101220234232.000|TR0|But lunar eclipses themselves are actually 
20101220234232.000|20101220234235.000|TR0|fairly common.  We usually have about one 
20101220234235.000|20101220234237.000|TR0|or two a year.  In 1982, we actually had 
20101220234237.000|20101220234239.000|TR0|about three of them.  And every once and 
20101220234239.000|20101220234242.000|TR0|again, we'll have a year where we'll skip 
20101220234242.000|20101220234244.000|TR0|them altogether.
20101220234244.000|20101220234246.000|TR0|
20101220234246.000|20101220234249.000|TR0|As I mentioned, the best time that we're 
20101220234249.000|20101220234251.000|TR0|going to see them is going to be between 1 
20101220234251.000|20101220234253.000|TR0|and 5.  We'll see this particular lunar 
20101220234253.000|20101220234256.000|TR0|eclipse. And the thing that's going to be 
20101220234256.000|20101220234258.000|TR0|really interesting about it is the color 
20101220234258.000|20101220234300.000|TR0|that we're going to be seeing.  Because we 
20101220234300.000|20101220234303.000|TR0|have got the moon actually behind the sun, 
20101220234303.000|20101220234305.000|TR0|and it casts the earth's shadow on the 
20101220234305.000|20101220234307.000|TR0|moon itself, it filters out many of the 
20101220234307.000|20101220234310.000|TR0|colors, so to speak.  Say the blue rays 
20101220234310.000|20101220234312.000|TR0|are actually going to be blacked out.  But 
20101220234312.000|20101220234314.000|TR0|the reddish colors are going to make it to 
20101220234314.000|20101220234317.000|TR0|the moon, giving it kind of a reddish hue. 
20101220234317.000|20101220234319.000|TR0| It should be quite beautiful to see.
20101220234319.000|20101220234321.000|TR0|

20101220235326.000|20101220235328.000|TR0|seven-month tour of duty on the USS Truman.

20101220235330.000|20101220235333.000|TR0|And near Mumbai, a seagull soars over the 
20101220235333.000|20101220235335.000|TR0|Arabian Sea.
20101220235335.000|20101220235337.000|TR0|
20101220235337.000|20101220235340.000|TR0|"Hot Shots," pictures worth a thousand 
20101220235340.000|20101220235342.000|TR0|words.

20101220235344.000|20101220235347.000|TR0|He has made it his business to expose 
20101220235347.000|20101220235349.000|TR0|delicate information about figures around 
20101220235349.000|20101220235351.000|TR0|the world, but when it comes to talking 
20101220235351.000|20101220235354.000|TR0|about himself, WikiLeaks founder Julian 
20101220235354.000|20101220235356.000|TR0|Assange has been practicing the art of the 
20101220235356.000|20101220235358.000|TR0|walkout a lot.
